Cranberry Sauce with Ginger

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the ultimate guide for making a delightful Cranberry Sauce with Ginger! This vibrant, tangy sauce is not only a staple for holiday feasts but also an incredible addition to your everyday meals. With the perfect balance of sweetness from fresh cranberries and a zesty kick from ginger, this recipe is designed to elevate your culinary repertoire. Whether you’re looking to complement your Thanksgiving turkey or simply crave a unique condiment for your sandwiches, this cranberry sauce will deliver that extra burst of flavor you desire. Plus, it’s quick and easy to prepare, making it ideal for novice cooks and seasoned chefs alike. Join us as we dive into the simple steps of creating this irresistible dish that will impress your family and friends!

Ingredients

fresh cranberries

Ensure the cranberries are fresh and vibrant in color, avoiding any that are soft or shriveled. If fresh cranberries are unavailable, you can substitute with frozen cranberries; just thaw them beforehand and adjust cooking time slightly as they may release more liquid.

sugar

Granulated sugar is standard for sweetness, but you can substitute with brown sugar for a deeper flavor, or use honey or maple syrup for natural sweetness. If looking to reduce sugar, consider using a sugar substitute, but check the conversion ratio as they can vary.

water

Water is used to dissolve the sugar and cook the cranberries. You can enhance the flavor by substituting some or all of the water with orange juice or apple juice for a fruity note.

fresh ginger, grated

Fresh ginger adds a spicy and aromatic flavor. If fresh ginger is not available, you can use ground ginger, but use about 1/3 of the amount since it's more concentrated. To make peeling easier, try using the edge of a spoon.

lemon juice

Fresh lemon juice brightens the flavor of the sauce. If you don’t have fresh lemons, bottled lemon juice can work, but be cautious as it may have preservatives which can alter the taste. For a twist, consider adding a splash of orange juice or zest for additional citrus flavor.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Cranberries

    Rinse the fresh cranberries under cold running water. Inspect them carefully and remove any stems or unsightly berries. This step is crucial as it ensures you have the freshest and best quality cranberries for your sauce.

  • Step 2: Dissolve the Sugar

    In a medium saucepan, combine 1 cup of water and 1 cup of sugar over medium heat. Stir the mixture continuously until the sugar is completely dissolved. This creates a sweet syrup that will balance the tartness of the cranberries.

  • Step 3: Combine Ingredients

    Once the sugar has dissolved, add the rinsed cranberries and 1 tablespoon of freshly grated ginger to the saucepan. Increase the heat to bring the mixture to a boil.

  • Step 4: Cook the Sauce

    After reaching a boil, reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook the mixture for about 10-15 minutes. You will notice the cranberries starting to burst open, releasing their natural juices, and the sauce will begin to thicken. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and ensure even cooking.

  • Step 5: Finish with Lemon Juice

    Once the cranberries have burst and the sauce has thickened to your liking, remove it from heat. Stir in 1 tablespoon of fresh lemon juice for a zesty finish. This will add brightness to the sauce and enhance its flavors.

  • Step 6: Cool and Serve

    Allow the cranberry sauce to cool at room temperature before transferring it to a serving dish. The sauce will thicken further as it cools. Serve it chilled or at room temperature, preferably with your favorite holiday dishes.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I wash and prepare fresh cranberries?

Rinse the cranberries under cold running water in a colander. Remove any stems or soft, spoiled berries. It's important to use fresh cranberries, as they provide the best flavor.

What is the best way to measure ingredients accurately?

Use dry measuring cups for solid ingredients like sugar and wet measuring cups for liquids like water. For sugar, fill the cup and level it off with a straight edge. For liquids, pour until the measurement hits the desired line, checking at eye level to ensure accuracy.

How do I know when the cranberries are cooked properly?

Cook the cranberries until they burst, which usually takes about 10-15 minutes. You’ll know they’re done when the sauce thickens and has a nice consistency. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.

What can I do if my cranberry sauce is too tart?

If the sauce is too tart for your taste, add more sugar a little at a time while cooking, tasting as you go until you reach your desired sweetness.

Is it safe to use a grater for fresh ginger?

Yes, using a microplane or fine grater is a safe and effective way to grate fresh ginger. Just be careful with your fingers and keep them away from the grater to avoid cuts.

How should I store leftover cranberry sauce?

Allow the cranberry sauce to cool completely, then transfer it to an airtight container. It can be stored in the refrigerator for up to two weeks or frozen for longer storage. Just thaw it in the fridge before using.

Can I make cranberry sauce ahead of time?

Absolutely! Cranberry sauce can be made a few days in advance. It's often even better after the flavors have had time to meld together.

What is the purpose of adding lemon juice?

Lemon juice adds a bright, acidic balance to the sweetness of the cranberries and sugar, enhancing the overall flavor of the sauce.

What if I don’t have fresh ginger?

If you don't have fresh ginger, you can substitute with about 1/4 teaspoon of ground ginger. It won't have the same fresh flavor, but it will still work in a pinch.

How can I make my cranberry sauce thicker or thinner?

To thicken the sauce, cook it a bit longer to reduce the liquid further. To thin it out, you can add a splash of water or juice while cooking until you reach the desired consistency.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This cranberry sauce is naturally gluten-free and vegan. For a sugar-free alternative, consider using a sugar substitute like erythritol or stevia. Additionally, to enhance the flavor, you can add spices like cinnamon or allspice, or mix in chopped nuts for extra texture.

Pairings

Cranberry Sauce with Ginger pairs beautifully with roasted meats such as turkey, chicken, or pork. For a vegetarian option, serve it alongside a nut loaf or a hearty vegetable dish. As for beverages, consider serving it with a sparkling white wine, like Prosecco, or a spiced cider to complement the zing of the ginger and tartness of the cranberries.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the cranberry sauce in a decorative bowl or jar to showcase its vibrant color. For an elegant touch, garnish it with a sprig of fresh mint or a twist of lemon peel. This sauce can be enjoyed warm or chilled, depending on preference; however, serving it chilled can enhance its refreshing qualities. It can also be drizzled over cream cheese or goat cheese for a delightful appetizer with crackers.

Cranberry Sauce with Ginger

30 min
$3.5
70 kcal
Difficulty: 10%
Servings: 8

Dietary Tags:

VeganGluten-FreeNut-Free

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Side DishCondiment

Tags:

EasyQuickSide DishHoliday

Description

A zesty twist on traditional cranberry sauce, infused with fresh ginger for a delightful flavor boost.

Ingredients

  • fresh cranberries: 12 oz
  • sugar: 1 cup
  • water: 1 cup
  • fresh ginger, grated: 1 tablespoon
  • lemon juice: 1 tablespoon
